dashboard.findings:
--At least 80% of respondents are somewhat or very concerned about the mental and physical health of students and employees alike.
--A large majority of respondents rate maintaining student engagement (81%) and ensuring student access (69%) as somewhat or very challenging issues for their institution.
--88 percent of respondents are somewhat or very concerned about the longterm decline in future student enrollment.
--Among long-term issues, respondents are most likely to be concerned about their
overall nancial stability (89% somewhat or very concerned).
--As a result of the uncertainties, nearly all respondents afliated with two-year programs want flexibility from state/federal governments on regulatory limitations for remote learning (93%).

dashboard.title: The Changing Landscape of Online Education Survey (CHLOE) 4: Navigating the Mainstream
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--The clear majority (61%) of COOs report that their duties are increasing, 35% are stable, and only 4% of COOs reported that their responsibilities are decreasing.
--There has been little attention to how institutions are preparing students for online learning. Among different sectors, four-year regional publics (16%), enterprise programs (20%), and flagship public institutions (20%) report the smallest proportion requiring such orientation, and four-year regional private institutions the largest (49%). Community colleges fall between these extremes (26%).
--Accessibility has become a universal commitment in U.S. higher education. In light of this commitment, it is, perhaps, more significant that over 40% of the CHLOE sample acknowledged that they currently fall short of achieving full accessibility than the nearly 60% that claimed to have already reached this goal.
--Roughly 60% of institutions in the CHLOE 4 sample require some form of online training for faculty. Less than 5% of institutions requiring faculty training report a waiver process to exempt faculty who meet certain criteria. The most common justifications for such waivers are prior experience at the institution in designing and/or teaching online or training at a previous institution.

dashboard.title: Survey of College and University Student Affairs Officers

dashboard.findings:
--Nearly all student affairs officers say they spent significant time in the past year responding to matters related to student mental health (94 percent) and student well-being (91 percent).
--A slim majority of student affairs officers evaluate race relations on their campus as either “excellent” (6 percent) or “good” (48 percent). 
--Sixty-eight percent of student affairs officers agree that students on their campus generally respect free speech rights. Seventy percent believe the same is true of faculty members at their college.
--Student affairs officers are much more likely to disagree (50 percent) than to agree (27 percent) that sexual assault allegations are best investigated by local law enforcement rather than by colleges and universities.

dashboard.title: The 2019 Education Next Survey

dashboard.findings:
--A majority of Americans (60 percent) believe that four year colleges should be tuition free, while even more (69 percent) believe that public-two year colleges should be free.
--Among the general public, 44 percent think that undocumented students should be charged in-state tuition instead of out-of-state tuition. There is a sharp partisan divide in this view - 67 percent of Democrats support resident tuition for undocumented students while only 20 percent of Republican agree.
--In general, more Americans have a more favorable view of their state higher education institutions than the view of higher education institutions nationwide (78 percent vs 58 percent).

dashboard.title: The Growing Partisan Divide in Views of Higher Education
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--Among all adults, 50 percent agree that college has a positive effect on the U.S., which is down from 63 percent in 2015. Only 33 percent of those who are Republican or lean Republican believe that college has a positive effect on the U.S., while 67 percent of those who identify as Democrats or lean Democrat believe that college has a positive effect on America.
--Since 2012, the number of Republicans who have a negative view on college has increased from 35 percent to 59 percent.
--Democratic support has been relatively stable over the past 7 years, hovering around 67 percent.

dashboard.title: Forging Pathways to Purposeful Work
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.sample_demographics: College graduates, hiring managers, parents of students who are college bound, in college, or recently graduated
dashboard.findings:
--80 percent of college graduates report that it is either extremely important or very important that they find purpose in their work; only 25 percent say that they have found their ideal job.
--Students’ experiences in their undergraduate career can also help them find purpose in a career. Only 23 percent of respondents strongly agreed that they were given realistic expectations for their employment prospects upon graduation.
--As students complete more internships during their undergraduate career, the likelihood of having high purpose in work increases. For example, for the nearly half (45 percent) of students who did not complete any internships, 21 percent of them reporting having high purpose in work. By completing one internship, this figure rises to 31 percent. 
--77 percent of respondents who find high purpose in work cite their interest in their specific area of work as important, as compared to the 23 percent who have low purpose in work but are working in a career field that is interesting to them.

dashboard.title: College and Univresity Business Officers
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.sample_demographics: Chief Business Officers, Senior Financial Officers
dashboard.findings:
--62 percent of chief business officers (CBOs) are confident about their institution’s financial outlook over the next five years.
--Less than half (45 percent) of CBOs agree with economists’ predictions that there will be an economic downturn before December of 2020.
--Community college CBOs report that their college is more reliant on state funds (39 percent) as opposed to public institutions’ reliance on state funds for a master’s or baccalaureate (33 percent).
--More than 90 percent of CBOs claim that they run periodic financial reports, which are often shared with other administrative officials.
--CBOs say that net operating revenues ratio, increase or decrease in unrestricted net assets, and rate of growth of net tuition are very important metrics used at their institutions to measure its financial health.

dashboard.title: Faculty Attitudes on Technology
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.sample_demographics: Faculty members and digital learning leaders
dashboard.findings:
--46 percent of faculty members report teaching an online course for credit, up from 39 percent in 2016 and 30 percent in 2013.
--More than 3 in 4 of faculty members who have instructed online courses say that the experience has taught them skills and practices that have improved their teaching. The most commonly reported skill is thinking more critically about how to engage students with course content and optimizing multimedia content.
--60 percent of faculty members believe academic fraud is more common in online courses than in face-to-face courses, while 39 percent believe that fraud occurs in equal amounts in an online course and in a face-to-face course.
--45 percent of digital learning leaders and 39 percent of instructors say that inclusive access platforms are achieving their two primary goals of reducing course material costs for students and improving education outcomes.

dashboard.title: College and University Admissions Officers

dashboard.sample_demographics: Admissions directors and enrollment managers from public, nonprofit, and for-profit institutions
dashboard.findings:
--86 percent of admissions directors said they were very or moderately concerned about meeting their institution’s new student enrollment goals for the 2019-20 academic year.
--Nearly two thirds (65 percent) of admissions directors report that their college has sought more out-of-state students in recent years, while more than 3 in 4 (76 percent) say that these recruitment efforts have been successful.
--About half (51 percent) of admissions directors agree that there is concern that people have lost faith in the fairness of the admissions process at U.S. colleges.
--A majority of admissions directors (60 percent) think that colleges should be permitted to consider race and ethnicity, among other factors, in college admissions. Private institutions are more likely to believe so than public institutions (47 percent vs 9 percent).
--58 percent of admissions directors strongly agree or agree they are worried about the trend of some public universities becoming as competitive in admissions as elite private institutions.

dashboard.title: Half in U.S. Now Consider College Education Very Important
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--Slightly more than half of U.S. adults (51 percent) classify a college education as “very important”. This is lower than the 70 percent of U.S. adults who gave a college education the same distinction in 2013. Adults who say a college education is “fairly important” has increased since 2013 from 23 percent to 36 percent; the percentage of adults who also say college is “not too important” has also increased, from 6 percent to 13 percent.
--Women and minorities see college education as more important than their majority counterparts: 57 percent of women report that a college education is very important, while 45 percent of men report the same. 65 and 66 percent of Blacks and Hispanics, respectively, believe that a college education is very important, while only 44 percent of Whites believe the same.
--Those who identify as Democrats have more favorable views on the importance of higher education: 62 percent of Democrats say that higher education is important. 50 percent of independents and 41 percent of Republicans say the same. All of these percentages are down from 2013, when 68 percent of Republicans, 62 percent of independents, and 83 percent of Democrats reported that higher education is very important.

dashboard.title: Young Americans' Views on the Value of Higher Education
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--A little less than half (48 percent) of young Americans see themselves either pursuing higher education at a four year college or are already attending a four year institution. Only 27 percent plan on attending or are already attending a community college, vocational school or trade school.
--Two thirds (67 percent) of young Americans who are attending or are planning to attend a four year college will finance their education by taking out a loan.
--As income rises, so is the likelihood that a person either plans to attend or is attending a four year college. 53 percent of students in households making between $50,000 and $100,000 plan to attend or are currently attending a four year college, compared to the 38 percent of students in households making less than $50,000. For students whose family income is greater than $100,000, this figure is 73 percent.
--Overall, 60 percent of young Americans believe that a bachelor’s degree is a good way to prepare for success, compared to the 73 percent who believe that on the job experience is a good way to prepare for success. 
--77 percent of young adults and 76 percent of teens agree that the affordability of higher education is an extremely/very serious problem. 95 percent of teens and 93 percent of young adults identify college affordability as a somewhat serious or very serious problem.

dashboard.title: Destination College - Exploring New Routes to Success

dashboard.findings:
--Many parents questioned the value of a US college education with respect to cost; 57 percent reported that college costs don’t justify the value of a college education, while 85 percent feel that colleges need to figure out a way to reduce costs and make college more affordable.
--Roughly eight in ten (79 percent) of parents agree that the role of college is to teach students marketable skills.
--Parents also recognized the importance of gaining social and critical thinking skills from college. More than three thirds (78 percent) agree that college is an important time to develop interpersonal and social skills, while 72 percent agree that college is the time to develop critical thinking skills.
--57 percent of parents either somewhat agree or completely agree with the statement that the best college education includes internships.

dashboard.title: NJ Residents Say College Is Worth It But Have Ideas for Improvement
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--An overwhelming number - 90 percent - of the New Jersey adults who have attended college say that higher education is worth the cost. Residents link college opportunity directly to the ability to find jobs, develop careers, and to improve the quality of life for families.
--Quality: 77 percent say NJ colleges are good or excellent; 86 percent say four-year colleges are seen as having the highest quality, contrasted to two-year and online colleges.
--Value: 90 percent of those who attended college find that the value of college is worth the cost. Top college outcomes include: getting a better job (31 percent) and improving the quality of life (27 percent).
--Best way to increase college value: respondents’ top answers were for colleges to provide more practical experiences, such as internships (33 percent); and for students to find more work and internship experiences (29 percent).

dashboard.title: Citizens View NJ Colleges As High Quality and Value

dashboard.findings:
--Citizens perceive colleges as high quality (78%) and high value for the investment (80%).
--College cost is viewed as the single biggest barrier to attending and completing college (70%).

dashboard.title: The Changing Landscape of Online Education (CHLOE)
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--The majority of our study’s sample view online programs as revenue generators rather than drains on resources. Online tuition is commonly the same as campus tuition with differential fees covering the perceived additional costs of online development and delivery. A significant segment (37%) of private nonprofits charge online students lower than campus tuition. Most institutions distribute online revenue to meet overall institutional needs.
--Most institutions anticipate supplementary, not transformative, changes in online learning in the coming years. Interest in new tools and learning strategies is diffuse and noncommittal. Faculty remains central to online course development. Instructional design support is widely available, but most often is optional at the faculty member’s discretion. In enterprise-level programs and many private nonprofits, however, design support is required.
--Less than quarter of institutions use online program management (OPM) providers to support online program promotion and development, and for many, such partnerships are supplemental. Larger programs and private nonprofits are likely to own their online courses, while shared or faculty ownership is more common in two- and four-year public institutions. In 40% of community colleges, faculty do not receive compensation for course development, while compensation is nearly universal among larger programs and private nonprofits.
--The majority of online programs have adopted quality standards for course design, program design, online faculty development, and student outcomes. Quality assurance for support services lags behind. The most commonly used input metrics are program reputation, faculty training, and faculty credentials. The most commonly used outcomes metrics are student retention/graduation rates, student academic achievement, and post-graduation student employment.

dashboard.title: The Changing Landscape of Online Education (CHLOE) 2: A Deeper Dive
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
-- Enrollment growth is still the most frequently cited strategic goal and the prevailing consideration in budget deliberations. Stability outweighs the temptations of continued rapid technological change in about three-fourths of institutions.
-- Enrollment growth is still the most frequently cited strategic goal and the prevailing consideration in budget deliberations. Stability outweighs the temptations of continued rapid technological change in about three-fourths of institutions.
--The presence of instructional design (ID) input in the course design process has a measurable effect
on student-to-student engagement and the consistency of course technology and pedagogy. The
predominant factors limiting this practice are cost and the preservation of faculty autonomy.
--Quality assurance measures are widely embraced, but only a third of programs seek external validation of quality, though many more state the intention to do so in the future.

dashboard.title: The Changing Landscape of Online Education (CHLOE) 3: Behind the Numbers
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--The majority of online courses are overwhelmingly asynchronous, though a significant number include
some required or optional face-to-face sessions. While some outliers are breaking the mold, the types of interaction – with materials, peers, faculty, and support staff – in a typical online course revealed consistency with a more traditional, classroom-based approach, across all sectors and models.
--Institutions still rely primarily on internal data – retention and graduation rates and achievement of program objectives – to judge the effectiveness of their online programs. The two most commonly tracked post-graduation measures are employment (36%) and alumni feedback (31%), with less than a quarter of schools tracking other post-graduation evidence.
-- Public two-year institutions are more focused on building courses than online or blended programs.

dashboard.title: Beyond Free College and Free Markets: Voters Want Greater Accountability in Higher Ed
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--An overwhelming majority of Americans believe that bachelor’s degrees (70%), associate’s degrees (69%), and vocational training certificates (90%) are “worth the investment and usually pay off,” with broad support for each of these credentials across party lines.
--an overwhelming majority of Americans believe that bachelor’s degrees (70%), associate’s degrees (69%), and vocational training certificates (90%) are “worth the investment and usually pay off,” with broad support for each of these credentials across party lines.
--Democrats showed higher support for ideas like increasing investment in the Pell Grant program (90%), establishing a grant program that provides additional resources to institutions dedicated to improving outcomes among low-income students and students of color (89%), and requiring college accreditors to consider student outcomes as part of their review of institutions (85%).
--A healthy majority (67%) of Republicans agree that, “the federal government should provide basic guardrails to ensure that students aren’t encouraged to take out loans to attend predatory institutions that will leave them worse off than when they first enrolled,” compared to only 33% who said “the federal government should not try to influence where students choose to attend college and spend their taxpayer-funded grants and loans.”
--Across the board, more than eight in ten voters said it was important (with 52% saying it was very important) for Congress to prioritize increasing guardrails to protect students from predatory and poor-performing schools. And while it’s not surprising that Democrats would feel this way (and 86% did), more than three-quarters of Republican voters echoed the same sentiment.

dashboard.findings:
--All together, 72 percent of Americans say they would support free tuition at public colleges and universities for qualified applicants.
--Despite the widespread desire for free college, a majority of Americans agree that college is worth its current high price tag: Nearly 6 in 10 Americans—regardless whether they attended college or not—say the cost of college is worth the investment.
--However, 36 percent of Americans say that college is not worth the cost. When this group was asked to choose which of two responses was closer to why they believe this, the majority (60%) said, “people often graduate without specific job skills and with a large amount of debt.” Alternately, 36 percent of the group who believes college is not worth it agreed with this statement, “you can get a good job without a four-year degree.”

dashboard.title: Perceptions of College Amissions Practices
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--In general, 38% regard the college admissions process as fair, while 36% consider it unfair. Another 25% say it is neither fair nor unfair. 
--Most Americans think high school grades and standardized admission test scores are and should be the most important factors in determining college admission.
--Many say a family’s finances should be less of a factor when evaluating college applications.
While 44% think donations made to the school are considered by colleges when determining a student’s admission, only 13% say it should have any significant bearing on admissions. And 46%
think colleges give weight to the family’s ability to pay full tuition, while only 23% think that should be a consideration.
--Among both whites and non-whites, 40% think colleges currently use race and ethnicity as a consideration for admission. Thirty-seven percent of non-whites believe this should continue, compared with 22% of whites.

dashboard.title: College Administrators Support Greater Accountability in Higher Ed
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--Three-quarters say “The higher education institution I work for could do more to help set students up for success.”
--When asked which should be a bigger focus for institutions, 58% think schools should concentrate more on improving quality over lowering costs (42%).
--When it comes to increasing graduation rates, leaders at higher education institutions believe students and colleges both have the power to improve them. On a scale of 0 to 10, colleges rank at 7.8 and students at 7.7 for their capacity to drive change in that area, while the federal government ranking is slightly lower at 6.1 (though only 24% said the federal government had no power to improve graduation rates, ranking it 4 or below).
--Looking at employment outcomes, administrators say colleges have the most power to improve them (7.5 on a 10-point scale), with students ranking next (at 7.3). Here the numbers for the federal government were slightly higher (6.5) than on graduation rates, and only 19% think it has no power in this area (4 or below).
--The responsibility index shifted slightly when it came to loan repayment. Here college administrators rank the federal government as having the most power to improve loan repayment rates (7.3), with colleges next in line (6.7). These higher education leaders rank students’ power to change loan repayment rates lower than any of the other actors we tested, including state government.

dashboard.title: Survey of Community College Presidents
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--Community college leaders largely endorse the idea of community colleges offering bachelor’s degrees and believe doing so would increase access to higher education and reduce the racial gap in degree attainment. They do not, however, believe states provide enough financial support to ensure the degrees are high quality.
--Nine in 10 community college presidents expect the trend toward free community college education to
continue. Three-quarters see free community college programs as helping to improve the image of community colleges in their local areas.
--Community college presidents continue to perceive that a lack of clear pathways for community college students to transfer two years’ worth of credit is a significant barrier to students transferring to four-year colleges to earn a bachelor’s degree. However, fewer now (81 percent) than a year ago (90 percent) hold this view.
dashboard.tags: learning, educational pathways, affordability, admissions and enrollment

dashboard.title: Survey of College and University Chief Academic Officers
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--Chief academic officers continue to rate the academic health of their institution positively: 86 percent describe it as excellent or good. However, this is the first time less than 30 percent evaluated it as “excellent” since Inside Higher Ed began asking this question in 2012.
--The vast majority of CAOs continue to view liberal arts education as central to undergraduate education. However, they widely believe the concept of liberal arts education is not well understood in the U.S. and that politicians and others are increasingly unsympathetic to liberal arts education.
--Two-thirds of chief academic officers believe higher education has tolerated sexual harassment by faculty members for too long, and a majority say they were not surprised by the number of cases of alleged sexual harassment in the past year.
--CAOs continue to endorse the idea of competency-based education, with 79 percent in favor of the approach. However, only about half of CAOs, 52 percent, say their college awards academic credit based on demonstrated competence. Private baccalaureate CAOs are much less positive about competency-based education.

dashboard.title: Suvery of College and University Presidents
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--The majority of presidents, 64 percent, believe colleges should reconsider their involvement with countries that do not respect basic human rights. Fifty-five percent say colleges should not set up branch campuses in countries that do not respect basic human rights.
--The vast majority of presidents believe textbooks and college course materials cost too much (87 percent) and that colleges should embrace free, open educational resources (85 percent). Presidents are similar to chief academic officers, but unlike faculty members, in saying a desire to save students money justifies the loss of some faculty control in course material selection.
--At a time of declining confidence in higher education, only about one in six presidents agree that most
Americans have an accurate view of the purpose of higher education. They widely believe that the public thinks college is less affordable than it is and that concerns about affordability are a key reason for declining support for higher education.

dashboard.title: Undergraduate Teaching Faculty: The HERI Faculty Survey 2016–2017
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--More than three out of five women (61.0 percent) believed they needed to work harder than their colleagues to be perceived as a legitimate scholar compared to just 43.6 percent of men.
--Overall, just over three-quarters (77.4 percent) of faculty agreed that women faculty were treated fairly at their institution. A significantly greater proportion of men (83.5 percent) than women (69.3 percent) agreed with this statement. While four out of five faculty (79.3 percent) perceived fair treatment of faculty of color at their institutions, significantly more Asian/Pacific Islander (83.8 percent) and White (81.0 percent) faculty tended to endorse this view than their Latino/a (58.8 percent) or Black (61.4 percent) colleagues.
--Overall, less than half of undergraduate teaching faculty (48.4 percent) feel satisfied or very satisfied with the relative equity of salary and job benefits. Faculty whose principal activity is teaching (72.2 percent) are less likely to be satisfied with the equity of salary and benefits than those whose principal activity is service to clients/patients (79.3 percent), administration(82.6 percent), or research(82.6 percent).

dashboard.title: Most Americans Say Colleges Should Not Consider Race or Ethnicity in Admissions
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--While majorities across racial and ethnic groups agree that race should not be a factor in college admissions, white adults are particularly likely to hold this view: 78 percent say this, compared with 65 percent of Hispanics, 62 percent of blacks and 59 percent of Asians (the Asian sample includes only those who speak English).
--Republicans and those who lean toward the Republican Party are far more likely than Democrats and Democratic leaners to say that race or ethnicity should not be a factor in college admissions (85 percent vs. 63 percent). These party differences remain when looking only at whites: 88 percent of white Republicans say that colleges should not consider race in college admissions, compared with 66 percent of white Democrats.
--When asked about eight admissions criteria that colleges may consider, high school grades top the list. About two-thirds of Americans (67 percent) say this should be a major factor; 26 percent say it should be a minor factor.
dashboard.tags: diversity and inclusion, equity, admissions and enrollment

dashboard.title: WGBH News Higher Education Poll: Top Line Data
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.sample_demographics: Non institutionalized persons aged 18 and over living in the U.S.
dashboard.findings:
--Seventy-two percent of disagreed with the Supreme Court's rulings that colleges can consider race in their admissions decisions. 
--Eighty-six percent responded that campus diversity is at least a somewhat important goal.
--The population is spilt on their willingness to pay higher taxes so that more residents of their state could afford to attend a state college or university; 47 percent support paying higher taxes and 49 percent oppose paying taxes.

dashboard.title: Why Higher Ed? Top Reasons U.S. Consumers Choose Their Educational Pathways
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.sample_demographics: Individuals aged 18 to 65, living in all 50 U.S. states and the District of Columbia
dashboard.findings:
--Fifty-eight percent of education consumers say getting a good job is their primary motivation, compared with 23 percent who report a general motivation to learn more and gain knowledge without linking it to work or career aspirations. 
--Fully 72 percent of those with postgraduate educational experiences say getting a good job is their top motivation, as do 60 percent of those on a technical or vocational educational pathway. Four-year degree holders (55 percent), two-year degree holders (53 percent) and noncompleting students (50 percent) are also most likely to identify work and career motivations.
--The 31 percent of noncompleters who name these general learning goals as their top reason for pursuing their educational pathways far exceeds the percentages among students who complete vocational/technical training (14 percent), postgraduate work/degrees (18 percent), four-year degrees (20 percent) or two-year degrees (25 percent).
--Location (28 percent) and access/affordability (22 percent) are the most common main reasons that consumers give for where they choose to enroll.

dashboard.title: 2018 Strada-Gallup Alumni Survey Mentoring College Students to Success
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.sample_demographics: Individuals with a Bachelor's degree or higher aged 18 and older, with internet access, living in all 50 U.S. states and the District of Columbia
dashboard.findings:
--Nearly two-thirds of recent graduates who agree or strongly agree that they had a mentor during college say that mentor was a professor (64 percent).
--Eighty-eight percent of graduates received at least some career advice from either faculty or career services.However, graduates are more likely to have received career advice from faculty or staff members than from the career services office. While a third of graduates say they received career advice from faculty or staff often or very often, 22 percent say the same about the career services office. 
--Graduates of private nonprofit institutions report the highest degree of academic rigor, with 52 percent strongly agreeing that they were challenged academically — followed by graduates of public (38 percent) and private for-profit (32 percent) institutions.

dashboard.title: Annual Survey of College and University Admissions Directors
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.sample_demographics: Senior person in admissions or enrollment management at a U.S. institution
dashboard.findings:
--Many college admissions leaders believe that the recent decision by the University of Chicago to end its SAT/ACT requirement will prompt other colleges to follow suit. And a majority believe that the emphasis on testing in admissions discussions discourages students from considering colleges where they could be admitted and thrive.
--A majority of college admissions leaders do not value the writing tests on either the SAT or the ACT and believe that better ways exist to evaluate the writing skills of applicants.
--More than two-thirds of colleges admit less than 5 percent of their students from waiting lists -- even at a time when college waiting lists seem to be growing. Most admissions directors believe that waiting lists are too long.

dashboard.title: 2018 Survey of Faculty Attitudes on Technology
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.sample_demographics: U.S. College and University faculty members and digital learning leaders
dashboard.findings:
--Forty-four percent of instructors said they had taught an online course, up from 42 percent last year and 30 percent in 2013.
--Professors who have taught online overwhelmingly say the experience improved their teaching and made them more likely to experiment with new approaches. 
--Three in 10 instructors (30 percent) said they believe online courses can achieve student outcomes comparable to those of face-to-face courses, down slightly from 33 percent last year. And professors are more likely to disagree than to agree that using digital tools can lower the per-student cost of instruction without diminishing quality.

dashboard.title: Americans' Views of Higher Education As A Public and Private Good
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.sample_demographics: Adults 18 years of age or older
dashboard.findings:
--Seventy-six percent of respondents see public spending on higher education in the United States as an excellent or good investment, returning benefits to individuals and society as a whole. 
--Women are significantly more likely than men, and younger Americans more likely than older ones, to view public spending on higher education as an excellent investment. In addition, urban Americans value investment in education more than their suburban and rural counterparts. 
--Racial and ethnic minorities are more likely than whites to say higher education institutions contribute to both the public good and to private interests.

dashboard.title: 2018 Pew Research Center's American Trends Panel
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--About six-in-ten Americans (61 percent) of Americans say that higher education (HE) in the US is going in the wrong direction.                                                                                                                                                                                   --Seventy-three percent of Republicans and those who lean to the Republican Party say higher education is headed in the wrong direction, whereas 52 percent of Democrats and Democratic leaners say HE is going in the wrong direction. 
--Younger adults are more likely to offer a negative opinion on HE: 61 percent of 18-34 year olds say HE is going in the wrong direction vs. 48 percent of 50 to 64 year olds who say the same thing. 96 percent of Republicans over the age of 65 say HE is on the wrong track due to professors political views. 
--Among Americans who say the country’s higher education system is going in the wrong direcstion, 84 percent cite high tuition costs as a major reason why they think this is the case. About two-thirds (65 percent) say students not getting the skills they need in the workplace is a major reason, while roughly half cite colleges and universities being too concerned about protecting students from views they might find offensive (54 percent) or professors bringing their political and social views into the classroom (50 percent).

dashboard.title: Varying Degrees
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.sample_demographics: Adults, aged 18 and over, from the continental United States, Alaska, and Hawaii
dashboard.findings:
--A majority of Americans say community colleges and public four-year colleges and universities are worth the cost (81 percent and 65 percent, respectively). Whereas only about two in five Americans believe that private (44 percent) and for-profit (40 percent) colleges and universities are worth the cost.
--Four out of five (81 percent) have a positive view of the higher education institutions near them.
--There is wide agreement (90 percent) that apprenticeships and skills training programs prepare students for a good standard of living.
--A majority (60 percent) believe government should spend tax dollars on higher education because it is good for society, compared with 27 percent who say students should fund it because higher education is a personal benefit.

dashboard.title: Survey of College and University Chief Academic Officers
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.sample_demographics: CAOs and Provosts from public, private, and for-profit institutions
dashboard.findings:
--Eighty percent of Chief Academic Officers (CAO) say free speech rights on campus are secure rather than threatened, and more than 8 in 10 say both students and faculty members at their college respect free speech rights. They are much less positive about the health of free speech rights on college campuses more generally and in the U.S. as a whole. 
--Eighty-four percent of CAOs say the concept of a liberal arts education is not well understood in the U.S. 
--Over five years, academic officers have grown increasingly likely to say that their college will increase its emphasis on cutting underpoerforming academic programs, dismissing underperforming faculty, promoting retirement of older professors, and increasing the use of part-time important.

dashboard.title: Survey of College and University Business Officers
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.sample_demographics: Chief business officers and senior financial officers
dashboard.findings:
--On average, CBOs estimate that 4.8 percent of their college’s operating budget is dedicated to debt service. Private institution CBOs dedicate a greater proportion of their budget to debt service than public institution CBOs do.
--Sixty-eight percent of CBOs expect the payout rate from their college’s endowment to stay the same over the next year, with more expecting their college will lower the rate than expect their college will increase it.
--Public college CBOs report a steady proportion of state funding supporting their budgets in the last, current and upcoming fiscal years. They say state funds account for roughly one third of their operating budget in the 2017, 2018 and 2019 fiscal years.

dashboard.title: Survey of Community College Presidents
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--A majority of community college presidents, 57 percent, say enrollment is down at their college over the past three years. Twenty-two percent report an increase in enrollment, and 20 percent report no change. 
--Three-quarters of community college presidents say their college is adding new programs on campus and adding options to make it easier to transfer to four-year institutions as a means of recruiting new students. 
--As they did last year, community college presidents are most likely to regard financial matters (71 percent) and enrollment management (68 percent) as big challenges for themselves and their peers.

dashboard.title: Survey of College and University Presidents
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--Forty-nine percent say the Trump administration’s handling of federal higher education has been about what they expected. But four times as many college presidents say the Trump administration has been worse (41 percent) rather than better (10 percent) than they expected.
-- The majority of presidents, 63 percent, remain confident that their institution is financially sustainable over the next five years. Fewer, 53 percent, agree their institution will remain viable over the next 10 years.
--In terms of enrollment, college presidents are most concerned about enrolling their college’s target number of undergraduates and about enrolling students who are likely to be retained and graduate on time. Private baccalaureate college presidents are especially concerned about meeting enrollment targets.

dashboard.title: Varying Degrees
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--Americans are split about whether there are lots of well-paying jobs that do not require a college degree. About half (51 percent) agree that there are lots of well-paying jobs that do not require college attendance.
--There is wide agreement (75 percent), however, that it is easier to be successful with a degree than without.
--Only a quarter of Americans agree that our higher education system is functioning fine just the way it is.
--Over half (57 percent) of Americans believe that colleges and universities should help their students succeed.

dashboard.title: Sharp Partisan Divisions in Views of National Institutions
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.sample_demographics: Adults, 18 years of age or older, living in all 50 U.S. states and the District of Columbia
dashboard.findings:
--A majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (58 percent) now say that colleges and universities have a negative effect on the country, up from 45 percent last year. 
--Most Democrats and Democratic leaners (72 percent) say colleges and universities have a positive effect, which is little changed from recent years.
--Since 2015, positive views of colleges and universities have fallen 11 points among Republicans with a college degree or more education (from 44 percent to 33 percent) and 20 points among those who do not have a college degree (57 percent to 37 percent).
--About half (52 percent) of Republicans ages 18 to 29 say colleges and universities have a positive impact on the country, compared with just 27 percent of those 65 and older. There are no significant differences in views among Democrats by age, with comparable majorities of all age groups saying colleges and universities have a positive impact.
--Wide majorities say colleges have a positive effect on the way things are going in the country, though Democrats with higher family incomes are somewhat more likely than lower income Democrats to say this. Among Republicans, nearly half of those with family incomes of less than $30,000 (46 percent) say colleges and universities have a positive effect, compared with only about a third (32 percent) of those with higher incomes.

dashboard.title: Why Are Republicans Down on Higher Ed?
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.sample_demographics: Adults, aged 18 and older, living in all 50 U.S. states and the District of Columbia
dashboard.findings:
--Thirty-three percent of Republicans, 56 percent of Democrats are confident in U.S. colleges.
--Republicans down on colleges cite politics, agenda, what is taught.
--Democrats down on colleges most frequently cite the high expense.

dashboard.title: The 2017 EdNext Poll on School Reform
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--Two thirds of the public would have their child pursue a four-year university degree, while only 22 percent would choose a two-year associate’s degree at a community college, and 11 percent would choose neither. These percentages do not change significantly when respondents receive information about both the costs and the earnings associated with each degree.
--75 percent of Democrats not provided information would prefer their child to pursue a four-year degree, as compared to 57 percent of Republicans.
--This partisan difference disappears when respondents receive information about the costs and benefits of the bachelor’s and associate’s degrees. When informed, the percentage preferring the four-year degree is 66 percent for Democrats and Republicans alike.

dashboard.title: Americans Losing Faith in College Degrees
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--A slim plurality of Americans, 49 percent, believes earning a four-year degree will lead to a good job and higher lifetime earnings, compared with 47 percent who don’t.
--While women by a large margin still have faith in a four-year degree, opinion among men swung significantly. Four years ago, men by a 12-point margin saw college as worth the cost.
--Among Americans 18 to 34 years old, skeptics outnumber believers 57 percent to 39 percent, almost a mirror image from four years earlier.

dashboard.title: College Student Survey: A Nationally Representive Survey of Currently Enrolled Students
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--Thirty-four percent and 36 percent of current students believe they will graduate with the skills and knowledge they need to be successful in the job market and the workplace, respectively.
--Thirty-nine percent of current students have never visited their school’s career services office or used their online resources.
--Fourty-six percent say their academic advisers provide very helpful guidance about which courses to take.

dashboard.title:
Education Consumer Pulse
Major Influence: Where Students Get Valued Advice on What to Study in College
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
-- Fifty-five percent of adults name a friend, a family member or — in fewer cases — a community leader as a source of advice about their major.
--Informal social networks have consistently been the most common source of advice for individuals, regardless of the decade during which they were enrolled. 
--First-generation college students and students who are pursuing a two-year degree are less likely than others to get advice about their major from their informal social network.
--Older enrollees are more likely than younger enrollees to consult work-based sources of advice about their major.
--When asked to rate the helpfulness of each source of advice about their major, people rate informal work-based sources of advice as most helpful, whereas formal sources of advice are rated as the least helpful.

dashboard.title: Survey of College & University Presidents
dashboard.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
dashboard.findings:
--Six in 10 presidents strongly agree or agree they are confident their institution is financially sustainable over the next five years.
--College presidents’ greatest concerns about enrollment are having enough institutional aid to enroll as many low-income students as their college would like to have, enrolling students who are likely to be retained and graduate on time, and enrolling their college’s target number of undergraduates.
--The vast majority of presidents describe the state of race relations at their college as either “excellent” (20 percent) or “good” (63 percent). More than three-fifths of presidents describe race relations at American colleges in general as “fair.”
--College presidents widely believe the public thinks that college is less affordable than it is because of attention to student debt levels, that colleges are wealthier than is the case because of attention to large endowments, and that colleges have misplaced priorities because of the campus amenities many colleges now offer students.
